welcome.data: Warm-Up Prompt: “What do you think a computer is? Where do you use computers in your daily life?” Students respond in a journal or notebook, then pair up for a brief share-out. Instructor gathers a few responses for whole-class discussion.

aim.data: Objective: Today we will explore the core components that make up a computer, and distinguish between hardware (the physical parts) and software (the instructions that tell it what to do).

review.data: Recap course goals and ask: “What do you already know about how computers work?” Conduct a quick K-W-L chart as a class (Know, Want to know, Learned).

relevant.data: Mini-lecture with slides on what a computer is, differences between hardware and software, real-world examples of both. Introduce core components like CPU, RAM, hard drive, motherboard, and common types of software such as operating systems and applications.

interactive.data: Activity: “Hardware or Software?” Students receive a list of 20 items (digital or printed) and work in pairs to label each as hardware or software. Discuss answers as a class and clarify any misconceptions.

ownership.data: Mini Project: Students create a labeled diagram of a computer system with at least 5 hardware components and 3 software applications. Submit digitally via photo or screenshot to LMS.

resonate.data: Exit Ticket: “Explain one way that software and hardware work together to make a computer useful.” Submitted via Google Form or paper.

supplies.data: Computers with internet access, projector or smartboard, slide presentation, printed or digital worksheets for activity, paper or drawing software for diagrams, exit ticket form or link.
